We begin with retired General Jack Keane, former acting chief of staff of the Army.

Well, you know, from the military component, it certainly does.
I mean, what we were advocating is a change of mission and definitely start to secure the population in Baghdad, which is an appropriate place to start, and that's what is going to take place.
When we analyzed that, we believed we needed about five additional brigades to what's already in Baghdad and what the Iraqis can produce to do that.

Well, you look at Baghdad, and like any military objective, I mean, you break it down into its parts, and you don't have to take on the whole city at once.

They waited two-and-a-half years in the harsh reality that one, the Iraqis couldn't protect them and the American military strategy chose not to protect them, and that's a fact.
And I think there's something to work with there.
And if they don't accommodate that desire after the evidence that we're protecting hundreds of thousands of their people, then we may, in fact, have to deal with them in Sadr City.
But I think the first step would be not to contest them in Sadr City, but to secure the Shias and the Sunnis in a mixed neighborhood.
That's the logical place to start.
